candidates.title: Move examples to root, refactor to workspace, and refactor integration tests
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context

Examples are important and yet hard to discover and use.

## Description

- Move examples from `aws-smithy-http-server/examples` to `examples`.
- Use `cargo` workspace rather than binaries
- Use `pokemon-service-common` to host common handlers and other types.
- Rework integration tests - they now exist as `/test` in the corresponding workspace crate.
- Merge `pokemon-service.rs` and `pokemon-service-connect-info.rs`
- Add `examples` to CI.
- Improve documentation

candidates.body:

The new WASM example requires compilation against another target, and thus, needs its own workspace. Rather than get clever about which examples can be in which workspace, this PR opts to make each individual example its own workspace.

## Testing
- [x] Pulled in the latest SDK examples (from https://github.com/awsdocs/aws-doc-sdk-examples/pull/4523) and verified they compile against the latest generated SDK with these changes

candidates.title: Fix test failure in `no-default-features`
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context
This PR fixes a test failure from `test_clients_from_sdk_config`. The test failure has prevented us from releasing a new version of `aws-sdk-rust`.

## Description
It is a negative test expecting a panic, but it failed because it panicked for a different reason, i.e. `no default sleep implementation available` instead of `No HTTP connector was available...`. The fix will add a default async sleep to a service config to ensure that the panic occurs for the expected reason.

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

candidates.title: Feature: Add smithy orchestrator
candidates.body:
[See the RFC for more details](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/2439)

This PR adds a new, common framework for constructing client requests and handling service responses. My intentions are to:

- Improve the user experience by
- Simplifying several aspects of sending a request
- Adding more extension points to the request/response lifecycle
- Improve the maintainer experience by
- Making our SDK more similar in structure to other AWS SDKs
- Simplifying many aspects of the request/response lifecycle
- Making room for future changes

Additionally, functionality that we currently provide like retries, logging, and auth with be incorporated into this new process in such a way as to make it more configurable and understandable.

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

candidates.title: Add connection poisoning to aws-smithy-client
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
- https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/160
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

## Description
Built on top of two changes to Hyper, this adds the concept of connection poisoning to Smithy client. To do this, we needed machinery to get access to the "connection metadata" used by the request. This is done in a connector agnostic way with the `CaptureSmithyConnection` bridge.

A separate layer considers the error classification then invokes poison as necessary. To support testing this, `WireLeveMock` was created, a mocking facility that binds to 0.0.0.0.

For AWS services, this behavior is **enabled by default**. For generic-smithy clients, this behavior is **disabled by default**.

## Testing
- integration test in S3
- detailed tests of specific behavior in aws-smithy-client

## Checklist
<!--- If a checkbox below is not applicable, then please DELETE it rather than leaving it unchecked -->
- [x] I have updated `CHANGELOG.next.toml` if I made changes to the smithy-rs codegen or runtime crates

----

candidates.title: Python: Add tests and fix the issues with `Timestamp` and `ByteStream`
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context
This PR adds tests for `Timestamp` and `ByteStream` types and fixes the discovered issues, namely:
- `Timestamp`: It was causing a compilation error previously if you add a `@required Timestamp` to your model
- `ByteStream`: There was a bug in the async next method (`__anext__`), which was causing Rust future to panic

## Testing
I've added some tests for the issues

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

candidates.title: Move using-native-tls-instead-of-rustls to smithy-rs
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context
Moves a `native-tls/rustls`-related test, `using-native-tls-instead-of-rustls` from `aws-doc-sdk-examples` to `smithy-rs`.

## Description
The test was previously in `aws-doc-sdk-examples` but it can be more useful to be in `smithy-rs` so it can catch a test failure early prior to cutting a release.

(`using-native-tls-instead-of-rustls` has been deleted from `aws-doc-sdk-examples` as part of [this PR](https://github.com/awsdocs/aws-doc-sdk-examples/pull/4469))

----

candidates.title: Add jitter to `LazyCredentialsCache`
candidates.body:
## Motivation and Context Addresses https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/2051 ## Description This PR adds jitter to `LazyCredentialsCache`. A jitter provides a mechanism for randomizing the [buffer time](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/d040f76fd1ae0295b9f4475d994e3dd4f4aa8893/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/lazy_caching.rs#L45) for credentials. This allows credentials with the same expiry to expire at slightly different times, thereby preventing thundering herds. The basic idea is borrowed from [the counterpart](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/blob/1c05fb6452a1f74985ff6deb7a642b9eb441274a/aws/credential_cache.go#L28-L40) in AWS SDK for Go v2. Note that adding a jitter does NOT modify the [expires_after](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/d040f76fd1ae0295b9f4475d994e3dd4f4aa8893/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/credentials_impl.rs#L36) field of credentials. Instead, it "tricks" `ExpiringCache` into thinking that the credentials' buffer time has been jittered. At the end of the day, the [expired](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/d040f76fd1ae0295b9f4475d994e3dd4f4aa8893/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/expiring_cache.rs#L101-L103) function behaves as intended.

In case 1, when no jitter is applied, the credentials' `expires_after` and [value's expiration](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/d040f76fd1ae0295b9f4475d994e3dd4f4aa8893/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/expiring_cache.rs#L22) in `ExpiringCache` point to the same value. If we subtract the buffer time from that timestamp, that's when the `expired` function starts returning `true`. In case 2, when a jitter is applied, the credentials' `expires_after` is still the same, and only the value's expiration in `ExpiringCache` is pushed back by the amount of the jitter. If we then subtract the buffer time from that timestamp, we get a new point at which the `expired` function starts returning `true`. The green bar is now shorter, meaning that we have effectively randomized the buffer time with respect to the credentials' `expires_after`. ## Testing - [x] Unit test `buffer_time_jitter` has been added. - [x] Passed tests in CI. ## Checklist - [x] I have updated `CHANGELOG.next.toml` if I made changes to the AWS SDK, generated SDK code, or SDK runtime crates ---- _By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._
